DOC.HEAD: Mississippi Catfish, Georgia Shrimp Hurt by Southern Freeze
DOC.TEXT: Mississippi catfish farmers may have lost up to one-fifth of an average monthly harvest because last week's big chill froze fish ponds solid, industry officials say. In Georgia, state biologists fear that recent freezing coastal temperatures will mean no chance for a healthy shrimp season next year _ more bad news for a shrimping industry already reeling from a poor fall crop and low prices. Most of the Delta's catfish processing plants reopened Friday after cold weather forced them to close for about a week. Mississippi processes about 7 million pounds of catfish weekly, or about 80 percent of the catfish consumed in the United States. From 26 million to 30 million pounds of catfish may have been lost, said Hugh Warren, executive vice president of the Catfish Farmers of America, a trade association. Industry officials said it will be at least another week before farmers know the full impact of the freeze. Thawing ponds are just beginning to reveal dead fish. More than 2,700 workers at the state's largest catfish processing plants have been off their jobs, he said. Farmers have suffered losses as high as 20 percent when ponds have frozen previously, said Dick Stevens, president of Country Skillet Processing Co. Country Skillet and Delta Pride Processors, two of the industry's largest companies, process about 60 percent of the nation's farm-raised catfish. ``The economic impact is very high,'' said Delta Pride President Sam I. Hinote. Ponds froze last weekend, some with 6 inches of ice, when temperatures dipped into the single digits. When ponds freeze, ammonia builds up and oxygen supplies dwindle, killing fish. Delta Pride's two processing plants in Indianola and one in Belzoni shut down Tuesday. Officials at Country Skillet said they halted operations at one plant and cut back operations at the other. Georgia Department of Natural Resource officials, meanwhile, began sampling waters in the Brunswick area Thursday and are expecting test trawls to net more dead shrimp than live shrimp as they move up the coast this weekend. The news comes a week after the department announced that the winter shrimping season, which normally ends Dec. 31, would be extended at least into January because of a bountiful shrimp supply. Biologist Gordon Rogers said if last weekend's freeze did the damage the department suspects, officials could rescind that announcement next week. ``At worst, it is our suspicion that there are no shrimp to be worrying about catching,'' Rogers said, adding that the state's prime white roe shrimp crop could be reduced for up to 18 months. White shrimp, which are caught in the spring, fall and winter, annually account for 80 to 90 percent of the Georgia crop. Brown shrimp harvested in the summer bring in 10 to 20 percent of the annual crop.
